Issues.Title: Compile errors when using async pipe with enableIvy & strictNullChecks
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package @angular/compiler-cli, @angular/angular ### Is this a regression? Yes, this works when Ivy is not used. ### Description The problem is the async pipe returns T | null. My understand is Ivy uses code similar to Partial> to check property bindings in templates. That allows undefined, but not null. Similarly, ngForOf doesn't allow null, so that also doesn't work with async. This causes templates that previously compiled without errors to fail. ```
  • {{n}}
``` We use ngrx/store, so we use the async pipe a lot, and for the most part the observables from the store will always return a value immediately. But async's return type means we have to deal with the null somehow even if it will never be emitted. I've come up with several workarounds, but I don't like any of them very much. And even if this is seen as behaving as intended, documentation should be updated (e.g. the example in https://angular.io/api/common/NgForOf#local-variables wouldn't work with strictNullChecks && enableIvy). Workarounds: 1) Using non null assertions [prop]=(value$ | async)!" I don't like this since I don't want developers to get used to throwing it around causally. 2) Use || to provide a default, *ngFor="let i of (array$ | async) || []" This works okay for the ngFor case, but doesn't work for the prop case if one of the valid values is falsey, or if there is no good default value. 3) Use ngIf with async, *ngIf="value$ | async as value" This is probably a good choice for the cases where the async pipe would legitimately be null, but is just needlessly cluttering template with ng-contianer or other elements in the cases where the async pipe will never return null. # üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 7.2.13 ### Description When running a 'build --watch' on a library project, the **rebuild** of the library project on any change does not import the string extension method e.g. String.prototype.func from another file. Initial build properly imports the function from the file and it works well. Suppose you are using the `cdkDropListSortingDisabled` directive. When you drag an item from the source, you left a placeholder behind, at the source list, while you're dragging.

When you finally dropped the item on the destiny list, you could finally decrease the number of available carrots and, eventually increase the number of carrots on your basket, without any place holder animation displacing items on the lists when the item type is already present on the origin/destiny lists.

The main point is: when you're dragging... is there a way to move an item from the source without actually erasing it from the source and drop it on the destiny without necessarily add a new item in the list there if some condition is present. Issues.Title: Drag drop on top of list item
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Use `cdkDropList` to drop an item on top of another `cdkDropList` item, rather than sorting a way to add it. It can be thought of as `cdkDropListMode='switch|over`.

#### Use Case

This enables pairing one list item(s) to a second list specific item, a behaviour different from the default sorting of `cdkDropList`.
In current way things work, setting `cdkDropListSortingDisabled` will prevent droping on to of a `cdkDrop` item, and event index will always be zero.

The new 'over' option of the `cdkDropListMode` can return the item being targeting index on `cdkDropListDropped` event.
It is useful in cases where drag and drop is used to assign an item with some options (demo below).

In addition, it makes sense that in such scenario, the item will be cloned, rather than being moved. This can be thought of as `cdkDragClone` on `cdkDrag` item.

Thanks
